summary: An analysis of Jackson Wang's viral speech in London and its impacts on the Chinese diaspora.

events_list.video_caption: The video features two individuals engaged in a podcast or interview, each holding a microphone. The person on the left, wearing a beige sweater and a black cap, is seated in front of a neon sign that reads 'HOT POT BOYS DAVID & ANDREW.' The person on the right, dressed in a pink jacket, is positioned in front of a blue neon sign that says 'UPSIDE DOWN.' Throughout the video, the two individuals are seen speaking and gesturing animatedly, indicating an engaging conversation. At one point, an image of a person with blonde hair and a news article headline appears on the screen, reading 'It's propoganda bulls***!': Hong Kong rapper Jackson Wang's emotional London concert tirade against anti-China media sparks flood of online support.' The article discusses Jackson Wang's speech during his concert in London, which received approval from thousands of fans. The video maintains a lively and dynamic atmosphere, with both individuals actively participating in the discussion.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male voice speaking with excitement about a pop superstar making candid remarks, causing an internet frenzy. A second male voice with a more casual tone mentions the speech was about celebrity and pursuing goals, but focused on the part where the celebrity proudly declared his Chinese heritage, regardless of media portrayals. The first speaker chimes in, announcing the clip playback and soliciting likes from Jackson Wang fans. There is a brief pause, then a glitchy sound effect, marking the transition to the next segment.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a person on stage, holding a microphone and a bottle, dressed in a black outfit with a green cap. The background features a large screen displaying abstract visuals in pink and purple hues. The person appears to be performing, with subtitles in English and Chinese at the bottom of the screen, translating to 'I'm sick of a lot of gossip when I'm an artist too much.' The scene transitions to a split-screen view of two individuals in a studio setting, each holding a microphone. The person on the left wears a beige sweater and a black cap, while the person on the right is in a pink jacket. Behind them are neon signs reading 'HOT POT BOYS DAVID & ANDREW' and 'UPSIDE DOWNSET.' The video then shows a close-up of the person on stage, with subtitles reading 'there's so much f****** media talking about b******,' indicating a critical commentary on media coverage. The person on stage continues to speak and gesture, with the background screen displaying a close-up of their upper body. The scene shifts back to the studio, where the two individuals continue their discussion, with the person on the left gesturing animatedly. The video then displays a series of YouTube comments, with one comment reading 'My man is grinding the social credit points for when he comes back to his homeland for his retirement. Some people can't spot jokes these days, especially the ones on YouTube replies.' The video concludes with the two individuals in the studio, continuing their discussion, with the person on the left speaking into the microphone and the person on the right listening attentively.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a rap song in a moderately upbeat tone, featuring percussion as its main instrument. It then transitions to a male speaker who is clearly giving a speech and stating that artists should not be hyped up too much and that they only sing, dance, and make music. The speaker is interrupted by the sound of a crowd cheering and shouting, with someone in the crowd shouting a word multiple times. A male speaker in a conversational tone discusses a range of reactions and debates from people who are part of the Chinese world, mentioning Jackson Wang. The audio clip ends with another male speaker who is also conversational and asking about a concert in London.

events_list.video_caption: The video features two individuals engaged in a podcast or interview, each positioned in separate frames. The person on the left, wearing a beige sweater and a black cap, holds a microphone and appears to be speaking, while the person on the right, dressed in a light pink jacket, listens attentively. Behind them, neon signs read "HOT POT BOYS DAVID & ANDREW" and "UPSIDE DOWNSET," indicating the names of the show and possibly the studio or location. Throughout the video, various comments from viewers are displayed on the screen, including one from "tsu1028" criticizing the show for not showing tattoos and fishnet shirts, and another from "JEB" encouraging pride in Chinese heritage. The setting is casual and conversational, with the individuals maintaining a relaxed demeanor as they discuss topics related to the comments shown.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing responses to someone named Jackson, reporting that one such response criticized Jackson's lifestyle and questioned his use of free speech while in London, labeling it hypocritical. Then another male speaker agrees and advises against being ashamed of being Chinese due to Western media, emphasizing the pride of their civilization.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a split-screen interview between two individuals, each holding a microphone. On the left, a person wearing a beige sweater and a black cap with the word "AWAKE" on it speaks into a microphone, with a neon sign in the background reading "HOT POT BOYS DAVID & ANDREW." On the right, another individual in a pink jacket speaks into a microphone, with a neon sign behind them that says "UPSIDE DOWNSET." Throughout the video, various comments appear on the screen, including one from "nnn" expressing concern about someone's health and alcoholism, and another from "Lisette" discussing the treatment of citizens in China and the actions of Jackie Chan. The setting appears to be a casual, indoor environment, possibly a studio or a home office, with plants visible in the background. The individuals seem engaged in a conversation, with the person on the left gesturing with their hand while speaking. The video maintains a consistent visual style, focusing on the dialogue and the comments displayed on the screen.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a male speaker, possibly in a broadcast, who sounds mocking and dramatic, stating "Oh my gosh, she's drinking on stage" followed by "Is she an alcoholic?". He then says "This reminds me of Kanye at the Grammy's with the Taylor Swift thing". The clip then transitions to a different male speaker, who speaks in a more measured, somewhat sarcastic tone, stating "Anybody can say anything good about their mother country if they're incentivized properly" before saying that if he were a pop star, he would also be "pretty positive too".

events_list.video_caption: The video features two individuals engaged in a podcast or interview, each positioned in separate frames. Throughout the video, various comments appear on the screen, such as one from 'free loonar' discussing political views and another from 'Tony Wu' mentioning 'chinese $$$$$,' indicating an interactive element with the audience. The individuals maintain a conversational tone, with the left speaker actively engaging and the right listener responding, creating a dynamic dialogue. The video maintains a consistent visual style, with the split-screen format and the presence of the comments providing context to the discussion.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker, presenting a critique, stating that people say, "All countries have good parts and bad parts," but in the West, one is only allowed to mention the "bad parts about China" and not the "good." He claims that someone spoke of "a little bit of good things." Then, another male speaker expresses his distrust, stating "Now I can tell," the speaker states anyone that doesn't say anything bad about China is "doing it for the moolah."

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a discussion centered around someone, presumably Jackson Wang, and their controversial statements. A person quotes someone else, stating that regardless of agreeing or disagreeing with Jackson Wang, he deserves credit for standing up for what he said, as his country of origin is allegedly being villainized by Western media. They express pride in him for speaking up, contrasting it with stereotypes about Asians. Afterward, another person questions the severity of the statements, summarizing that he merely pointed out an anti-China bias in Western media and suggested that visiting China might surprise people. The first person responds, suggesting the media attention was due to how he made the statements and that if he had used different language or wasn't drinking on stage, it would have been perceived differently. They emphasize he's representing a perspective.

events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with two people, one male with an energetic tone stating there's a "spectrum", and another male agreeing. He describes a "westernized Chinese guy" being proud, then shares an anecdote of being in Seoul in 2017 for an Asia World Tour, messaging with Jackson Wang when he was in Got7. The first speaker interrupts stating he knows "through a friend of a friend".

The speaker then imitates the other person's voice and tone. The speaker expresses that what the other person did was "a very Western thing".

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a conversation between two male speakers. The first speaker initiates with an observation about American culture, characterizing it as common to step on stage and exclaim, "Nah, man, I'm tired of this, let me tell you how I feel," and referring to it as a "Tupac moment" jokingly. The second speaker responds to this characterization, noting that it's not that big of a deal to him, apart from the format of the expression, and referring to the speaker's shirt. He describes the act as representing "a pretty moderate perspective" opposing the "main perspective in the West right now," delivered like a "fiery moderate perspective". The first speaker then asks what this argument really comes down to. The second speaker responds and discusses how the arguing on the Internet that followed the clip was from different sides of the Chinese diaspora.

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features two male speakers discussing the complexities of being Chinese, particularly for American-born Chinese individuals. One speaker describes the topic as "super, super complicated," noting that many ABCs opt out of discussions about China due to the extensive research and "soul searching" required. The other speaker agrees, mentioning that some ABCs avoid engaging with friends who express negative opinions about China, either to avoid conflict or be seen as a "China hater." They acknowledge the complexities, and the polarizing nature of China. The overall tone is conversational and reflective.

events_list.audio_caption: Two male speakers are in conversation, one saying "Listen, listen, it's this country that is supposed to take over the world but at the same time everyone's also saying it's going to collapse." The other speaker agrees, saying that everyone also thinks you can beat up any single Chinese person in America. The first speaker replies, agreeing but stating it's the big dog that's going to take over America with AI. The second speaker agrees, remarking that the situation is very convoluted.

events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with two people having a discussion about Chinese food not representing China, followed by the complicated views on Chinese nationals and purchasing property. The conversation moves to Chinese students, scientists returning to China, and then to the Chinese diaspora, where they feel pressure to remain neutral. The mood shifts as the speakers describe the situation as very complex. Light background music plays throughout the conversation.

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing what American-born Chinese (ABCs) do, mentioning how they might say, "I'm just gonna eat the food and celebrate Chinese New Year", but not want to talk about it. He suggests people believe they can't impact the situation and agrees an individual cannot, but it's strange that they can be negatively affected. Another male voice agrees, noting you can't improve things but can feel the downside. The first speaker agrees. He thinks that's why ABCs try to detach from the whole thing. The clip ends there.

events_list.audio_caption: Two male speakers engage in a casual, conversational dialogue. One speaker invites listeners to share their opinions on Jackson Wang's work and their personal experiences and feelings about their Chinese identity. He emphasizes that everything sparks debates nowadays and invites viewers to like their videos. The other speaker ends the segment with the parting word "Peace,". This dialogue is accompanied by music with a lighthearted and positive tone.
